info.game_comments:
Cindy Stowell game 6.

WE ASKED: Ana Navarro.

double_jeopardy_round: THE MUSICAL STYLINGS OF JOHNNY GILBERT

(1, 1).clue: From 1954 to 2003 Strom Thurmond served this state in the U.S. Senate

(2, 1).clue: Mike Tyson, claiming he was fouled before biting off part of this boxer's ear: "I have to retaliate"; not like that, Mike!

(4, 1).clue: Yeats called Rupert Brooke "the handsomest man in England"; sadly, the foxy poet died young in this 20th century conflict

(5, 1).clue: I'm versed in this public speaking skill & find that standing at a lectern works best

(6, 1).clue: Just before July 4, 2016, Jason Galvin freed one of these American symbols stuck high in a tree

(1, 2).clue: (I'm Senator Al Franken.)  As a U.S. senator discussing such issues as farm policy & jobs training, I've visited all 87 counties, from Lake County in the northeast to Rock County in the southwest, in this, my home state

(2, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew demonstrates.)  In football, this is the signal for a false start; in basketball, it's the signal for this violation

(4, 2).clue: Sorry, Hef--a bio of debonair Porfirio Rubirosa, linked to half the starlets of the '50s, is titled "The Last" this

(5, 2).clue: I wouldn't mind sitting like other members of this group, but I guess nobody made me take up the xylophone

(6, 2).clue: A boy who survived a tsunami wearing the jersey of this national team was helped by Cristiano Ronaldo & is now a young soccer star

(1, 3).clue: Prior to becoming governor of New Jersey in 2010, this Republican served as a United States attorney

(2, 3).clue: Etiquette from a leading association for this activity includes "never" do it "in street shoes"

(4, 3).clue: Next time you dream of Manderley, dream of this dreamy author of "Rebecca"

(5, 3).clue: Defending my client, I stand in court & shout this word to let the judge know I disapprove, procedurally

(1, 4).clue: (I'm political commentator Ana Navarro.)  In 1999 I served as the first director of immigration policy for this governor of Florida

(2, 4).clue: In the NHL this penalty isn't for using a credit card, it's called on a player "who skates or jumps into... an opponent"

(4, 4).clue: A Venetian visitor described this 16th century king of England as "the handsomest potentate I ever set eyes on"

(5, 4).clue: As part of this type of training with my unruly whippet, I have to stand & call his name over & over

(1, 5).clue: This long-serving Alaska senator survived a 1978 plane crash that killed his wife, but a 2010 crash would prove fatal for him

(2, 5).clue: Zinedine Zidane headbutted his way out of the 2006 World Cup as this country of his fell to Italy

(4, 5).clue: She was Miss Teen Ohio & Miss Ohio USA before winning an Oscar for "Monster's Ball"

(5, 5).clue: Life in the cult is tough at first--they make us stand during this 11-letter introductory part

(1, 1).clue: A little glasnost of champagne with the Reagans was the order of the day for this leader in December 1987

(2, 1).clue: To leave your waiter 45% instead of 15%

(3, 1).clue: If an 1860s New Yorker was told, "The boss wants to see you", it might be this "Boss" in his mansion at 5th Ave. & 43rd St.

(4, 1).clue: This Caribbean nation is divided into 14 parishes, including Saint James & Kingston

(5, 1).clue: James Whitcomb Riley wrote a poem about this "Little Orphant" girl; Harold Gray later created a comic strip about her

(6, 1).clue: "Hello from the other side.  I must have called a thousand times, to tell you I'm sorry"

(1, 2).clue: Guest chef Rick Bayless fed Mexico's president beef in this black Oaxacan sauce

(2, 2).clue: Some play ball with reckless this, which can also mean "to forsake"

(3, 2).clue: Until it was dissolved & absorbed by Napoleon in 1806, Francis II led this 1,000-year-old empire

(4, 2).clue: Naturally, magnolia trees surround the 1903 state capitol building in this city

(5, 2).clue: This 3-named American's "Psalm of Life" says, "Art is long, and time is fleeting"

(6, 2).clue: "G's to the bizzack, now ladies here we gizzo, when the pimp's in the crib Ma, drop it like it's hot, drop it like it's hot"

(1, 3).clue: To honor this newly elected world leader, the White House served a variation of poutine at a 2016 state dinner

(2, 3).clue: To free from ambiguity is this "C" verb, you "C" what I mean?

(3, 3).clue: This Scottish hero was defeated by Edward I at the 1298 Battle of Falkirk

(4, 3).clue: Ujung Kulon National Park on this Indonesian island is home to an endangered species of rhinoceros

(5, 3).clue: The stories he told to Peter & Michael Davies in Kensington Gardens were first published as "The Little White Bird"

(6, 3).clue: "Haters gonna hate, hate, hate... baby I'm just gonna shake, shake, shake, shake, shake, I shake it off"

(1, 4).clue: In 2015 Japan's prime minister was served toro tartare made from the belly of this animal

(2, 4).clue: To walk or strut with defiance, man that guy's got some serious...

(3, 4).clue: This infamous quartet implemented Mao Zedong's harsh policies during the Cultural Revolution

(4, 4).clue: Sir Walter Raleigh was once governor of this largest of the Channel Islands

(5, 4).clue: In 1964 the Supreme Court said a 30-year-old novel by this Brooklyn guy was not obscene

(6, 4).clue: "1, 2, 3, they gonna run back to me, they always wanna come, but they never want to leave, ex's & the oh, oh, oh's"

(1, 5).clue: Ulysses Grant's dinner for King Kalakaua of these islands (including Hawaii) likely didn't include the food of that name

(2, 5).clue: What a sad dog may do; T.S. Eliot made it the opposite of a bang

(3, 5).clue: In 1950 this Israeli parliament passed the Law of Return, allowing Jews to go to Israel & get immediate citizenship

(4, 5).clue: Cret de la Neige is the highest peak in this range that straddles the border between Switzerland & France

(6, 5).clue: "I took a pill in Ibiza to show Avicii I was cool and when I finally got sober, felt 10 years older"

(0, 0).clue: If this U.S. state was a country, it would have been in the top 10 in gold medals with 14--9 of them by 1 man & 1 woman
